ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This was a really great class. I have a lot more confidence in my writing and reading of poetry. JDM was very helpful; he's so sassy. He has so many super-funny anecdotes: "That one time I approached Elizabeth Bishop," etc. It was a chill experience and you get to read some great stuff. I heard that the reason you should take creative writing classes is to give yourself space to reflect/think. This course definitely does that. If you get in, I definitely think you should take it.

I would definitely recommend English 460 to another student. It's a great way to improve your writing, while also exploring contemporary poets and poetry. It's quite time-consuming, but it's definitely worth it!

The Writing of Verse is a good grounding in poetic forms, one that gives experience in writing a variety of poems I certainly would never have written otherwise. There's also the opportunity to workshop and revise, and a selection of readings by and about poets and poetry. If you want a class that will push you to write poetry, this is a great place to start. Do make sure in shopping week that Professor McClatchy suits your style, since he's a lot of fun but the class is very much shaped around his personal attitudes of poetry/teaching.

If you are enthusiastic for poetry, this is a must-take course and will improve your writing mechanics a great deal. The workload is manageable but you're going to have to put in the effort in improving if you are to improve.
